document_title: Cystitis: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
In addition to asking medical history and examining, the doctor may ask the patient to perform some tests such as:
Urine test: When a bladder infection is suspected, the doctor will instruct the patient to take a urine sample to check for the presence of white blood cells, blood cells, and nitrite reaction. In some cases it is necessary to culture for bacteria.
Cystoscopy: A scope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder to capture images inside this organ, helping the doctor observe and evaluate damage in the bladder. During cystoscopy, the doctor may remove a small sample of tissue for laboratory testing (biopsy).
Imaging tests: X-rays or ultrasound will help doctors detect urinary tract abnormalities such as bladder stones, prostate enlargement, urethral stricture, etc.
